question: The kidney stone whose development is seen most commonly is:-
exp: Commonest stone seen in in kidney - Calcium oxalate Other types of kidney stones : Triple phosphate - Ca, NH4+ ,MgP04 Uric acid Cysteine stones

question: Mesangial deposits of monoclonal kappa/Lambda light chains in indicative of:
exp: Mesangial deposits of monoclonal kappa/lambda light chains suggest the diagnosis of Amyloidosis. Renal amyloidosis is the most common cause of death due to amyloidosis Amyloid deposition begins from mesangium and involves other pa later Clinical features - proteinuria , urinary cast present , kidney size increases. In primary Amyloidosis AL protein is deposited in the organs, which is made of light chains (usually lambda type) of immunoglobulins.

question: Nephrocalcinosis is seen in all except:
exp: Nephrocalcinosis Diffuse deposition of calcium salts in the interstitium of the kidney associated with sarcoidosis, milk alkali syndrome and distal renal tubular acidosis Not associated with medullary cystic kidney. (DISTAL A= TYPE ONE A =STONE )

question: Most common infectious agent associated with chronic pyelonephritis is:
exp: Chronic pyelonephritis: Bacteriological examination of the urine reveals: E.Coli ( most common ) Proteus species Streptococcus faecalis Pseudomonas species Microscopic features: Tubular thyroidization (filled with colloid casts) Interstitial fibrosis and inflammation Obliterative endaeritis of vessels

question: Which of the following is the least likely cause of necrotizing papillitis of kidney?
exp: Necrotizing papillitis/ Renal papillary necrosis. When infection of renal pyramids develop in association with vascular diseases of the kidney or with urinary tract obstruction. DM is the commonest cause TB is the rarest cause of papillary necrosis. Acute papillary necrosis: Diabetes mellitus Sickle cell disease Chronic alcoholism Vascular disease Analgesic abuse nephropathy

question: Which of the following is not true about Berger's disease?
exp: Berger's disease (IgA nephropathy) Frequent cause of gross or microscopic hematuria. Mild proteinuria is frequently present Occassionally nephrotic syndrome may develop.
opa: The pathological changes are proliferative and usually confined to mesangial cells
opb: Hematuria may be gross or microscopic
opc: On immunofluorescence deposits contain with IgA and IgG
opd: Absence of associated proteinuria is pathognomic

question: The Electron Microscopy is viually diagnostic in renal biopsy study of:
exp: For Alpo syndrome, the most diagnostic morphologic lesion is seen only by electron microscopy as an irregularly thickened GBM, with splitting of the lamina densa into interlacing lamellae that surround electron-lucent areas.

question: Fibronectin nephropathy has all of the following features except:
exp: Fibronectin nephropathy Autosomal dominant mode Proteinuria (MC presentation) and slowly progressive loss of renal function. Serum Fibronectinlevels are normal. Light microscopy: Glomerular enlargement and PAS ([?]), trichrome-positive but amyloid (-) mesangial deposits. Electron microscopy: Large (giant), mesangialand subendothelial electron-dense deposits.
opc: Glomeruli do not stain for immunoglobulin or complement

question: All of the following are associated with low complement levels except:
exp: Nephritic syndrome associated withlow C3 : Immune complex glomerulonephritis Post streptococcal glomerulonephritis Lupus nephritis Cryoglobulinemia Bacterial endocarditis Shunt nephritis Membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis Crescenteric glomerulonephritis Idiopathic proliferative glomerulonephritis Atheroembolic renal disease Sepsis Acute Pancreatitis/ advanced liver disease

question: A 7 year old boy presented with generalized edema. Urine examination revealed marked albuminuria. Serum biochemical examinations showed hypoalbuminemia with hyperlipidemia. Kidney biopsy was undeaken. On light microscopic examination, the kidney appeared normal. Electron microscopic examination is most likely to reveal:
exp: The child is presenting with features likely of Nephrotic syndrome whose most frequent cause in children is minimal change disease or lipoid nephrosis or nil disease Light microscopy there is no abnormality whereas on electron microscopy there is fusion of foot processes of the glomerular epithelial cells with normal glomeruli.
opa: Fusion of foot processes of the glomerular epithelial cells
opc: Deposition of electron dense material in the basement membrane

question: A child presented with edema, massive proteinuria and hyperlipidemia. True statement about this condition is:
exp: Glomerular barrier function depends on the molecular size (the larger, the less permeable) and charge (the more cationic, the more permeable) is done. The anionic moieties present within the capillary wall including the acidic proteoglycans of the GBM and the sialoglycoproteins of epithelial and endothelial cells are responsible for the viually complete exclusion of albumin (also having anionic charge) from the filtrate.
opc: Foot process of glomerular membrane normal
opd: Glomerular function is lost due to loss of polyanionic charge on both sites of glomerular foot process

question: All are true about nephronophthisis except:
exp: 2 types of cystic disease affecting the renal medulla are : 1. Medullary sponge kidney Relatively common Usually innocuous condition Associated with nephrolithiasis 2.Nephronophthisis- Medullary cystic disease complex Associated with renal dysfunction. Cause of chronic kidney disease that usually begins in childhood. Coical tubulointerstitial damage and not hyperophy occurs in nephronophthisis.

question: Hyaline aeriolosclerosis can be associated with all of the following conditions except:
exp: Malignant Hypeension Associated with Hyperplastic aeriolosclerosis - onion skin appearance of blood vessel. This lesion occurs in severe hypeension; vessels exhibit concentric, laminated("onion-skin") thickening of the walls with luminal narrowing. The laminations consist of smooth muscle cells with thickened, reduplicated basement membrane; in malignant hypeension, they are accompanied by fibrinoid deposits and vessel wall necrosis (necrotizing aeriolitis), paicularly in the kidney .

question: In which of the following conditions bilateral contracted kidneys are characteristically seen?
exp: Benign Nephrosclerosis, Kidneys are either normal or moderately reduced in size on gross appearance. Loss of mass is due mainly to coical scarring and shrinking. In kidneys, the Aeriolar narrowing caused by hyaline aeriosclerosis leads to diffuse vascular compromise and nephrosclerosis ( glomerular scarring ) leading to bilateral contracted kidneys.

question: All are non-proliferative glomerulonephritis, except:
exp: Conditions with Proliferative Glomerulonephritis : SLE (paicularly class II) HIV Membranoproliferative/Mesangiocapillary glomerulonepritis Neoplasia (CLL and MALT lymphoma) Post streptococcal glomerulonephritis Rest all options are the conditions with non proliferative glomerulonephritis.
